awd_titl_txt: Excellence in Research: Cominuscule Quantum Schubert Cells and Faddeev-Reshetikhin-Takhtajian (FRT) Bialgebras
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates a series of interrelated problems in quantum algebras and noncommutative ring theory.  The term quantum group is used to describe a large class of algebras which can be thought of as deformations of classical groups and algebras. Some important examples of quantum groups include the quantum enveloping algebras of semisimple Lie algebras and the quantized coordinate rings of algebraic groups.  Quantum groups originated in physics, but have since played important roles in multiple areas of mathematics, such as topology and statistical mechanics.  The original path to constructing the quantized coordinate ring of an algebraic group is through a universal bialgebra construction due to Faddeev, Reshetikhin, and Takhtajian. The bialgebras arising from this construction are now commonly referred to as universal FRT-bialgebras.  Quantum Schubert cell algebras are another family of algebras of interest in this research project.  These are certain subalgebras of the negative (or positive) part of a quantized enveloping algebra. They have played important roles recently in the context of quantum cluster algebras and braided symmetric algebras.  We will study relationships between FRT-bialgebras and quantum Schubert cell algebras as well as their ring-theoretical properties. This project expands opportunities for student research involvement drawn from the predominantly underrepresented minority student population at North Carolina Central University.

In several important cases, quantum Schubert cell algebras may be regarded as quantized versions of unipotent Lie algebras. The most famous examples of quantum Schubert cells are the algebras of quantum matrices.  Other important examples include the algebras of quantum symmetric matrices and quantum anti-symmetric matrices. In this research project we will study ring-theoretic properties of these types of algebras, such as their quantum determinants, quantum minors, and quantum Pfaffians.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Determining the automorphism group of a given algebra is a notoriously difficult problem.  However in some special cases, particularly when the algebra is noncommutative, there may be relatively few automorphisms, and thus the automorphism group can be completely described. In this research project, the PI and co-PI studied the automorphism problem for quantum Schubert cell algebras, and developed some general techniques for identifying certain invariant subspaces.  These techniques were applied to q-nilradicals (quantum Schubert cell algebras associated to parabolic Weyl group elements) to completely determine the automorphism groups in those cases when the underlying Lie algebra is of type F4 or G2, as well as when the q-nilradicals are the algebras of quantum symmetric matrices (a type C q-nilradical).  Additionally, a conjecture regarding the automorphism group of a general q-nilradical was formulated; this conjecture states that the automorphism group is generated by the diagonal automorphisms together with the automorphisms induced from Dynkin diagram symmetries.

Motivated by our progress made on the automorphism problem, we studied quantum analogs of ad-nilpotency and Engel identities in quantum Schubert cell algebras.  For each pair of Lusztig root vectors (i.e. algebra generators), X_i and X_j with i < j, we found the smallest natural number k (called the nilpotency index) such that ad(X_i)^k sends X_j to zero, where ad is the q-adjoint map.  One of our main results is that the nilpotency index is bounded above by M + 1, where M is the largest coefficient on the highest root (written as an integral combination of simple roots).  Moreover, an efficient algorithm was found that returns the nilpotency index for any such pair, X_i and X_j. As it turns out, bigrassmannian Weyl group elements, which have appeared in a variety of algebro-geometric and combinatorial contexts, play an important role in our analysis. It is our hope to use nilpotency indices to construct invariants and thus gain some further control over automorphisms.  We also constructed algorithms for finding explicit presentations of quantum Schubert cell algebras in terms of generators and relations, which seems to be lacking in the literature.

Along a different line, the PI and A. Jaramillo discovered a connection between Type-A q-nilradicals and algebras of coinvariants with respect to the (quantum analog of the) coaction induced from the action of the Levi subgroup, by left multiplication, on a standard parabolic subgroup of SL(n). In particular, it was shown that these algebras are isomorphic. A presentation of the Type-A q-nilradicals was found. Using a presentation previously found by A.  Jaramillo for the algebras of coinvariants, an explicit isomorphism bewteen q-nilradicals and algebras of coinvariants was given.

Through partial support from this project, one MS degree student completed a master's thesis on commutation relations among quantum minors in the algebras of quantum symmetric matrices. Another graduate student as well as an undergraduate student received research training through this project.

Lectures on these results were given at numerous conferences and seminars.
